div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.

div.p: The Military School annual athletic sports will take place on the Obseratory parade ground, Abbassieh, on Thursday, 27th inst.

div.head: Delta Light Railways
div.p: The annual sports of the employes of the Delta Light Railways will take place at Damanhour on the 22nd inst.

div.head: Popular University
div.p: M. Pachundaki will lecture at the University on "The Prehistoric Man" on Saturday next, at 9 15 p.m. Ad- mittance is free

div.head: Stray And Ownerless Dogs
div.p: found in the Ain Chams district of Cairo during dawn on Friday, and in the Khalifa district during the night on Friday and dawn of Saturday, will be poisoned by the police.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 11 vessels passed through the Canal on the 10th inst., 7 of which were British, 3 German, 1 Dutch. The day's receipts were frs. 235,985.70, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 3,259,515.61.

div.head: The Opera House
div.p: The demolition of the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, and its recon- struction have, it seems, been decided on in principle, but no definite decision has been, come to as to when the work will be put in hand.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways
div.p: The Board of Administration informs us that the new Benha passenger station will be opened for traffic on the 15th inst.; but the goods traffic will continue to be dealt with at the old station, as at present.

div.head: Abbas Helmy Theatre
div.p: The collection or ganised by three actresses of the Coquelin Cadet company for the benefit of Gatti’s circus troupe, who suffered by the Abbas Helmy Theatre fire, amounted to frs. 1,700. This morning the sum was handed to the Italian Consul.

div.head: Union Syndicale Des Agriculteurs
div.p: The annual general meeting of the union will be held at San Stefano on Saturday next at 6.30 p.m., when a report on the past year will be read, and a proposal to remove the head- quarters of the union will be discussed. A banquet will follow the meeting.

div.head: Easter Holidays
div.p: The management of the Tewfik Palace Hotel offer to-residents desir- ous of spending the Easter holidays in Helouan unusual terms of P.T. 50 per day for full pension. The same terms will be charged to those wishing to make a lengthy stay. Riding, lawn-tennis, golf, shooting, and rifle practice will be in full swing.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is expected to return to Cairo from Montazali on Saturday evening.
A.S.C.
Programme of music for to-morrow’s Race Meeting.

1. March—Army and Marine—Zehle. 2. Overture—Le Caid—Thomas. 3. Selection-The Orchid—Caryll. 4. Dance—My Sweetheart—Boggetti. 5. Selection—Carmen—Bizet. 6. Marche—Indienne -Sellenick. 7. Valse -Espana—Waldteutel. 8. Intermezzo—Under the Moon— Reusch. 9. Selection—La Cigale—Caryll. 10. Dance—Cossack—Tschakoff. Khedivial Anthem—God Save the King. S. Dore, Bandmaster, 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. ‘‘Niger” arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria yesterday morning.
The Cunard S.S. “Veria" sailed direct for Liverpool this morning at daylight with a full cargo, including 1,739 bales cotton and 24,531 bags onions.

OPERATION DE BOURSE

div.head: THE LOTTERY LAW. DISTURBANCES AT CAIRO. MR. CATTAOUI’S HOUSE ATTACKED.
div.p: The discontent with the enactments of the new lottery law culminated in an extraordi- nary scene which took place at Cairo this morning.

The law came into operation on Monday, and since then the police both in the Capital and at Alexandria, have been most energetic in putting a stop to the sale of lottery tickets in the streets. The hawkers of these tickets, who were very numerous, have found that their occupation has come to an end and great discontent has ensued. A con- siderable number of those public vendors of lottery tickets are Jews, and they have been especially annoyed with the leading members of their community at Cairo for not, as they think, protecting them against the rigours of the new law by intervening on their behalf.

These men considered that their source of livelihood need not have been sacrificed if their richer brethren had Brought influence to bear on their behalf and their resentment has found a vent in the person of Mr. Cattaoui.

This morning a crowd of out-of-Work Jewish lottery ticket hawkers made their way to that gentleman’s house. Their attitude was most menacing and a number of the men forced their way into the house. The police had meanwhile been summoned, and a strong force of mounted and foot police appeared on the scene. Tho mounted policemen succeeded in dispersing the mob, and six of tho ringleaders have been arrested.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE. THE FOUNDLINGS’ GALA.
div.p: The success of yesterday evening’s "repre- sentation de gala" at the Zizinia Theatre can only be described as colossal, and the long and varied programme was gone through without a single hitch. The fete had been organised for the benefit of the Alexandria AFoundlings’ Insti- tution, and for many weeks past most elaborate preparations had been made to ensure success. The committee of this worthy charity includes Mme. Pierre Girard, honorary president; Comtesse de Zogheb, president; Mme. Christian Sinano, vice president, and Mesdames Abbat, Charles Bacos, Chataway Bey, Gabriel Debbano, Poilay Bey, Fred. Simond, Socolis, Emmanuel Zervudachi, Georges Zervudachi, and Alex de Zogheb. These ladies are to be congratulated on the success which has attended their efforts for the financial result of last night’s perform- ance should place the charity on a satisfactory and permanent footing. The theatre presented a brilliant aspect, and was filled with a repre- sentative gathering of all sections of society at Alexandria, including the Duke of the Abruzzi, Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun, and Prince Haidar.

The first part of the performance consisted of a concert. The vocal items were equisitely rendered by Mme Briend, Miss Claire Ricard, and Miss Verita, while teo musical portion of the programme fell to such well-known local musicians as Messrs. Affendoulis, Suzan, Ca- pozzi, Sheridan and Eurlich. A great feature of this part of the entertainment was the fine recitation by Poilay Bey of Baron Jacques de Menasce’s magnificent poem, "Les Bonnes Euvres.” The concert was followed by that very amusing farce "Monsieur Tranquille.” Here again Poilay Bey was an immense success and his efforts were admirably seconded by Messrs. Rodocanachi and Lumbroso, who succeeded in keeping the audience intensely amused by their vivacious acting.

The second part of the evenings entertain- ment was the fairy pautomine, "Cinderella.” For a long time psst tales have been bruited about of the fortunes that had been spent on the dresses, and the superb mounting of the pantomine. But the most extravagant rumours had not been exaggerated, and the gorgeous- ness of the mise en scene and the magnificence of the entire performance beggar description. The story, which was in dumb show, was ar- ranged by Poilay Bey after Perrault, while the music had been skilfully adapted by Mr. Nicholas Sinadino. A clever prologue was composed and recited by Mr. Rodocanachi. The story does not need telling, but it is no exaggeration to say that the mounting of the pantomime could not have been surpassed any- where. All those who took part had spared no expense on their dresses and costumes, and the grouping of the performers and the expert gracefulness of the dancing showed that no pains had been spared on rehearsing. Cinder- ella’s role fell to Mrs. Charles Bacos, who im- personated the heroine with a girlish grace which was as natural as it was charming. Her Two sisters were Mrs. Critchley and Missde Tschudyy, who, quite contrary to the usual pantomime traditions, rivalled the beauty of their neglected sister. One of the most beautiful effects of the pantomime was the make up of the Fairy Godmother, Mme de Planta, whose magnificent costume became her splendid figure to a nicety. Mrs. Chataway looked and acted the part of the Queen and her dress was much admired. Mr. Caravia as Prince Charming and Mr. Constantinides as the King were very good. Poilay Bey was again a tremendous success as the Lord High Chamberlain. It would be invidious to single out any of the lesser parts where all were so good, but among the Dukes the costume of Baron Alfred de Meuasce was especially admir- ed, and he looked very striking in his Vandyck garb. We must reserve full descrip- tive details for another issue, but we must not omit to mention the Cake Walk at the con- clusion, in which Baron Rene de Menasce and Mr. Ramsay brought down the house.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN INVESTMENT AND AGENCY, LIMITED. STATUTORY MEETING IN LONDON.
div.p: The statutory meeting of the Egyptian In vestment and Agency (Limited) was held at Winchester House, London, E.C., on the 7th inst., at 12 o’clodk noon. Sir Frederic Fryer, K.G.S.I., chairman of the company, presiding. The Secretary (Mr. Chas. I. Gardiner) having read the notice convening the meeting,

The Chairman said :- Gentlemen, —This company was registered on the 9th of January 1905, There was a phenomonal subicription, which amounted to £3,527,678. The prelimin- ary expenses, which were estimated at £2,500, amounted to £3,831.8.11. The excess was due to a larger number of shares being applied for through brokers, and bankers, than was anticipa- ted. One of our directors, Mr. Mack, has resign- ed his seat on the Board, owing to his absence from England, and to the pressure of his other business. Another director, Mr. Sellon, is, I regret to say, too ill to attend. We have a good deal of business in view in Egypt. As yet we have merely realised a small profit in thw shape of dividends and interest in the ordinary course of business. Our managing director in Egypt has, however, ten or twelve promising invest mentsts in view. The situation in regard to them is not sufficiently advanced to go into details regarding them. The flotation of one company by our company is practically complete, and the flotation of another is very near comple- tion. The Board expects that these flotations will show substantial profits when they have been brought to a successful issue. At our next meeting it will be possible to go more into detail, and it may be trusted that our business will by then have developed into a profitable, and paying concern. We have the greatest confidence in Mr. Abdy, who has given every attention to our interests. A representative of the company has spent a little, over a month in Egypt, and has been in consultation with Mr. Abdy. Owing to the distance of Egypt from London, it takes some time for full information of proposed trans- actions to reach London, and therefore, as was stated in the prospectus of the company, wide powers have been given to the local management in Egypt. It will, we confidently expect, soon be amply demonstrated that these powers have been made good use of. As regards the prosperity of Egypt,-it seems to have come to stay, as it is due largely to the fact that, owing to continued security in Egypt, the natives of the country and Levant- ines are producing and using wealth wich, during old troubled days, lay dormant and unknown. This latent wealth has now come to light and a new era of commercial and indus- trial prosperity has opened for Egypt. Our company has been formed concurrently with this new cycle of prosperity, and will, it may be trusted, be of benefit to Egypt in directing the disposal of the accumulated wealth of the country into useful channels.

div.head: IMPORTANT SALE OF LAND.
div.p: The Wakfs Administration sold on Thursday last a part of the lands on tho Rhoda Island belonging to the estate of the late Aly Pasha Cherif, which, being situated near the north end of the island, will not fail to benefit large- ly by the opening of the new Nile bridges. As miight have been expected, the price obtain ed at the auction was higher than that lately paid for adjoining land, and we hear that the purchasers, Messrs. Zervudachi, have also bought up a lease that had five years to run on part of the land.

div.head: THE DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI.
div.p: A largely attended reception was given yesterday afternoon on board the Italian cruiser "Liguria”.
The Duke of the Abruzzi attended the Zizinia Theatre yesterday evening. This morning at 8 o’clock the "Liguria" left Alexandria for Spezzia.
The Duke was graciously pleased to accept a copy of the work "Il Signor Marejo" from Signor Marchi Matteo.
His Royal Highness received in audience yesterday Abbate Pasha.

div.head: PRINCE COLIBRI.
div.p: Through the kindness of the courteous im- presario of this startling exhibition, we were enabled to satisfy our curiosity as to the truth or otherwise of the statement that “His Highness," whose height was given as 23 1/2 inches, only weighed 7 lbs. 10 ounces. Upon the suggestion of his manager that we should see for ourselves, we visited the Alhambra Theatre yesterday afternoon about 6 p m. Hero we were formally introduced to "Prince Colibri," who, upon rising from his tiny chair (which might have served for a doll’s house) offered his hand and bade us welcome in excel- lent English. Resuming his seat, he entered upon a lively conversation, during which we had an opportunity of convincing ourselves that we had certainly seen “the smallest man in the world.” His manager was good enough to allow us to take "His Highness" in our arms and place him upon the ground, very much to the amusement of the ladies and gentlemen present, who declared the com- parison to be accurately suggestive of a scene from “Gulliver’s Travels." His Highness ap- peared to appreciate his released position, and strutted lightly across the room with all the dignity of his title. He is a smart little fellow, although 23 years of ago ; and quite distinct from other similar freaks of nature, in being perfectly symmetrical, and even hand- some in appearance. We shall be surprised if the public do not take the opportunity afford- ed them of inspecting this remarkable speci- men of humanity, which should have special interest for the medical faculty. He is on view daily, from 5 till 11 p.m.

div.head: AMATEUR ATHLETIC SPORTS. THIRTY FIRST ANNUAL MEETING.
div.p: This great annual sporting event at Alex- andria came off yesterday on the A. S. C. grounds in glorious weather, the heat of the sun being tempered by a deliciously cool breeze. Notwithstanding the fact that the reception held on board the Italian cruiser "Liguria” by the Duke of the Abruzzi drew away a number of people who would otherwise have been present, there was a bumper attend- ance of the public, the grandstand and enclo- sure being crowded, while the usual contingent of carriages lined the other side of the course in a double row. The members of the fair sex turned up in full force, and gave a bright colour to the surroundings. Some of the frocks worn were very smart indeed, and more than one called for especial admiration. Where so many were pretty, however, it would be in- vidiuus to single out any particular ones for special mention, though eo may remark that the pervading colour was white. Children, too, were there in their numbers, and fairly revelled in the sports.

The entries for the sports were far ahead o last year's, and taken all round the perform- ances were better, although the adverse wind quite spoiled the times in all the events except the half mile. The handicapping was cer- tainly very good, as exemplified by the close finishes in many events, and by the fact that there were no less than three dead heats for either second or third. Handicapping is a very thankless task, but we think the four gentle- men responsible for yesterday’s starts and penalties are to be congratulated on their work. We also think the revised scale of points for Lord Cromer's Championship Cup is a great improvement, and mediocre performers are now much less likely to be accidentally styled “champion.” Yesterday's champion (J. R. Lees) fully deserved his honor, as he is a good all-round athlete.- He picked up his points all along the programme, and although heonly got one first, that-first marked him as the fastest man on the course. He was deservedly applauded as he came up to get his cup. Callender, as usual, won the shot putting, but by a very small margin from his generously handicapped opponent. (Callender has now won four clocks for 1st in this event. If he intends winning it again next year might we suggest a change of rewards). McLean, the veteran athlete, this year has been the unfor- tunate victim of several accidents in training and appeared on the course after two weeks' abstention from the path and well-bandaged. He won the pole jump with 8ft. 3in., no further height being necessary, but his injuries prevent- ed him from doing himself justice in the hurdles and long jump. Byrne’s jump of 18ft. lOin. was a good one. Woodley deserves special mention as the winner of the 150 yards, 220 yards, and quarter-mile handicaps. He has run several times before but has never been so successful. His starts were a bit longer than last year's, but he was well trained and finished his races very strongly. Thurston annexed the high jump and got second in the pole jump. Blyth- man, who was second in the hundred yards, was expected to win the half, and to do well in the quarter, two races in which he occupied the post of honor, but the pace in both was either too hot, or he was off colour and could only get in fourth in each. Peel, who won the half-mile in good time, is the third member of the same family who has won this race.

At the conclusion of the sports the prizes were kindly distributed by Mrs, E. B. Gould, to whom the committee presented a handsome bouquet. The course was in excellent condi- tion and reflects great credit on the clerk of the course, Mr. F. C. Haselden, to whom also is due the intricate construction of the obstacles in the obstacle race. The thanks of the com- mittee are due to Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield and to the steamship companies. Prince, Moss, and Khedivial, for the flags, etc., with which the grand-tand and course were profusely decorated. The bands of the R. Berkshire Regiment discoursed a choice selection of music during the afternoon, which was greatly appreciated. Mr. Percy Carver’s absence was greatly felt, and we trust his trip home will thoroughly re-establish him after his recent illness. Mr. S. H. Carver took his place as judge this year and, with Mr. G. C. Stevenson, ably discharged the onerous duties. The referee was seldom requisitioned.
The following are the results of the various events:—
150 Yards Handicap.—1st prize, Silver Cup (presented by Mahmoud Pasha Sidky) ; 2nd prize, Silver cigarette combination case ; 3rd prize, Claret jug.
E. H. Woodley (6 yards) 1st. C. Carmichael (10 yards) 2nd R. G. MacLaren (6 yards) 3rd.
15 entries. Carmichael looked all over a winner until five yards from the tape, when Woodley passed him and won by half a yard. Third close up. Time, 16 3/5 secs.

100 Yards Open.—1st prize, Silver Cup (presented by the Alexandria Ramleh Railway); 2nd, Travelling clock ; 3rd, Claret jug. Ali Fehmy Ahmed (pen. 3 yards) 1st. Ali Fehmy Selim 2nd. Hassanein Fehmy 3rd ( 11 entries. Won by half a yard. Time, 11 3/5 secs.
Puttinq the Shot.-1st prize, Clock (pre- sented by P.W. Carver, Esq.); 2nd, Biscuit box.
A. R. Callender (scratch) 1st. R. B. McLean (allowed 4ft.) 2nd.
8 entries. Callender’s put of 33 ft 9 in. brought him in half an inch in front of Mc Lean, who, with his allowance, put 33 ft. 8 1/2 in.
100 Yards Race — 1st prize, Silver Cup (presented E. B. Gould, Esq.); 2nd, Case salt sellars ; 3rd, Biscuit box.

19 entries. Lees, the favorite for this, came away from the start and kept his lead, passing the post a winner by a yard and a half ; a desperate tussle between Blythman and Mc Lean for 2nd place ended in favor of Blythman by inches. Inches again separated McLean rom Byrne. Time 11 3/5 secs.
High Jump (Handicap).— 1st prize, Bino- culars ; 2nd, Gong (presented by Mr. and Mrs. C. D. Stacey).
1st. H. F. Thurston (allowed 4 in.) 5 ft 4 in. 2nd S.R.P. Carver (allowed 2 in.) 5 ft 3 in. J. R. Lees (allowed 2 in.) 5 ft 3 in.
Eight entries. This competition was a great improvement on last year’s.
200 Yards Open Race.—1st prize, Silver watch (presented by the Alexandria Tram- way Co.) ; 2nd, Gladstone bag; 3rd, Inkstand.
Aly Fehmy Ahmed (Sc.) 1st. Kamal Allam (15 yds.) 2nd. Aly Fehmy Selim (5 yds.) 3rd.
Aly Fehmy Ahmed corkscrewed his way through the crowd and won by a yard. A foot between second and third. Time, 24 3/5 secs. There were 23 entries for this event.
220 Yards Handicap.— 1st prize, Kit bag (presented by Alexandria Staff of the E.T.C.) ; 2nd, Silver cigarette box; 3rd, Gold sleevelinks.
E. H. Woodley (7 yds.) 1st J. R. Lees (Sc.) 2nd. R. G. MacLaren (8 yds.) dead heat 3rd P. J. Brynce (2 yds.)

Lees, the scratch man, got through his men and led with 20 yards to go, but then Wood- ley, who seemed to stay the better, passed him and won by half a yard, Bryne and MacLaren being bracketed third a yard behind. Time 25 1/5 seconds.
Sack Race. (Open to Army and Navy).— 1st prize, £1 ; 2nd, 10s. ; 3rd, 5s.
Pte. Fowler, R. Berks, 1st. Pte. Norris, R. Berks, 2nd. Pte. Barley, R. Berks, 3rd. '
This race, as usual, caused great amuse- ment and was won easily by Pte. Fowler. Pole Jump.—1st prize, Leather trunk (pre- sented by H. H. Prince Omar Pasha Tous- soun) ; 2nd, Case of razors.
Owing to Haselden’s scratching this was easily won by R. B. McLean with 8 ft. 3 in., Thurston being second with 7 ft. 3 in. McLean was penalised 9 inches.
440 Yards. Handicap.—1st prize, the Temple Shakespeare (40 vols.) ; 2nd, “Encyclopedia of Sport;" 3rd, Menpes’ “Japan.", (All pre- sented by the Ladies of Alexandria and Rsmleh.)
E. H. Woodley (10 yds.) 1st. E. G. MacLaren (15 yds.) 2nd. P. J. Bryne (3 yds.) 3rd.

Betts, off the 15 yards start, looked a winner until 30 yards from the tape, when he broke down and MacLaren came on, but tiring ra- pidly he allowed Woodley to deprive him of first place by inches only, with Byrne a good third. There were 13 entries. This is the closest finish we have ever seen in the quarter mile. Time, 56 1/5 secs.

Children’s Race.—This was, as usual, pro- ductive of much merriment, there being thirty- six juveniles in the race, all of whom receiv- ed a prize. The race was won by Master Burrill, with Miss Mollie Briscoe second.
120 Yards Hurdle Race. —1st prize, Pic- ture (presented by S. H. Carver, Esq.); 2nd, Silver butter dish ; 3rd, Pair of flower pot stands.
1st heat.
S.R. P. Carver (owes 9 yards), 1st; H.F. Thurston (owes 4 yards), 2nd. Carver won this by a couple of yards from Thurston. MacLaren was left at the post. Time 20 4/5 secs.
2nd heat.
C. Carmichael (owes 4 yards), 1st; J. R. Lees (owes 9 yards), 2nd. McLean (owes 15 yards) was expected to annex this heat but his in- jured ankle kept him from securing a place. Time 20 1/5 secs.
Final heat.

S.R.P. Carver (owes 9 yards), 1st; C. Car- michael (owes 4 yards), 2nd; J. R. Lees (owes 9 yards), 3rd. Won by Carver, after Carmichael looked like scoring, by a yard and a half; thared a couple of yards away. Time,19 4/5 secs. European Boys’ Race.— 1st prize, Silver watch (presented by G. B. Alderson, Esq.) ; 2nd, Travelling clock ; 3rd, Knife.
W. Trulock, 1st. H. Elsworth, 2nd. T. Bent 3rd.
Won by a yard ; rest close up.
Veterans’ Race.—1st prize, Gladstone bag; 2nd, Ice pail and tongs ; 3rd, Pair bambou dishes.
Freeman (pen. 2 yards) 1st. Tweedie, 2nd. Burrill (pen. 1 yard) 3rd.
A good race, which Tweedie might have won but for having ran anything but straight This was Freeman’s second successive win. There were six competitors.
Native Boys’ Race. - 1st prize,Silver watch; 2nd, Travelling clock ; 3rd, Knife.
Abbas Zewan, 1st. Ali El Abani, 2nd. Ahmed Shukri, 3rd.
Obstacle Race.— Pte Fowler, 1st. The obstacles this year were very good, and the race proved interesting and amusing. Long Jump.—1st prize Tantalus (presented by F. Allen Esq.); 2nd, Silver Cup.
P. J Byrne (allowed 3 inches) won this with a net jump of 18ft lOin., J. T. Atkin being second with 17ft lOin.
Half Mile Handicap.—1st, Silver Cup (presented by E. A. Benachi, Esq.) ; 2nd, Set of carvers ; 3rd, Pewter.
E. T. Peel (15 yards) 1st. J. R. Lees (10 yards) 2nd. R. G. MaxLaren (30 yards) 3rd.

This was one of the best races of the day, the time also being good. Peel made the pace very hot from the start and led round the hurdle. Nearing the tape Lees made a big effort to overhaul him, but didn’t manage it, Peel winning by three yards, with MacLaren inches in front of Blythman, the scratch man. Time, 2 mins. 10 secs.
Tug Of War.—Royal Garrison Artillery 1st. No. 3 team Royal Berkshire Regiment 2nd. The Fire Brigade beat the Police in their confined tug of war.
Champion.—J.R. Lees, 25 points.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lady Wingate, wife of Major Gerard Sir F. R. Wingate, the Sirdar, has arrived at Stafford House, Dunbar, from Egypt, for the season.

We regret to announce the death of General Frederick Gasper le Gramd, Royal Marine Light Infantry (retired), who commanded the Ma rines of the Fleet, about 1,000 strong, when they lander at Alexandria after the bombard- ment, and subsequently commander the de tachment which occupied Port Said.

We regre to learm of the death, which took place at Cairo on Tuesday, of Colonel Temple. The funeral of the deceased took place yester- day and was attended by, among others, Lord Cromer and General Bullock.

Yesterday, at All Saints’ Church, Cairo, the marriage took place of Miss Blanche Harley and Mr. George Ludolf. The wedding party started from Miss James's Nursing Home, Mr. Du Boulay giving away the bride, who looked very well in a dress of cream voile over silk and a becoming Leghorn hat with white feathers and chiffon trimming. Among those present at the ceremony were Dean Butcher, Mrs. du Boulay, Mr. P. du Boulay, Mrs. Roussin, Mrs). Ross, Miss Elinor Frizell, and Mr. Mortimer. Mr. and Mrs. Ludolf leave Ghezireh Palace Hotel for Assiout to-morrow.

The marriage arranged between Mr. Max E. Steinauer and Lina, daughter of Brewster Bey, the popular English Secretary to H.H. the Khedive, and Mrs. Brewster, will take place at St. Joseph’s Church, Cairo, on the 26th inst., at 4 p.m. A reception will afterwards be held by Mrs. Brewster at the Grand Continental Hotel.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place on April 29, between Dr. N.H. Alcock of St. Mary’s Hospital, London, and Lilian, eldest daughter of the late Sir John Scott, K.C.M.G., some time Judicial Adviser to the Khedive and Assistant Judge Advocate General.

Major MacMahon, R.A., F.R.S., accom- panied by Mr. Heine, is spending a few days in Egypt on his way to England. Major MacMahon is a well-known savant deeply interested in the study of Oriental problems.
The President of the Quarantine Board re- turned to Alexandria yesterday evening from Tor and Cairo.

div.head: PASSENGER Lists.
Departures.
div.p: Per N.D.L S.S. "Schleswig," left Alexandria yesterday for Marseilles:- Miss Florence Abraham, Mr. John Burnaly Atkins, Mr. Freiherr and Baronin von Adels- heim, Mile Freiin von Adelsheim, Mr. Oreste Aceettulli, Misa C. Barwell, Mr. Ernest W. and Miss M. Bellhouse, Lady Bisset, Mr. Hugo Berger, Hon. W. Calthorpe, Mr. Charles Contour, Miss Cochran, Mrs. F. B. M. Creaton, Mme Cassar, Mme Rieh. Dietterle, Mr. Zaki Daghistane, Mr. and Mme Alfred Eckhardt, Mrs. Fenwick, Mr. Gaheimrat Prof. Dr Fraen- kel, Mr. Alfred Flugge, Mr. J. div.head: TYROL.
div.p: Weissentein Castle 3410 ft. First-class private hotel near Windisch Matroi ; Station, Liens (reached from Venice or Trieate). Good mountaineering centre. Tennis. Fishing, best June and September. Prospectuses and Pho- to graphs, “Egyptian Gazette” office, Cairo.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
River Transport of Good Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.
Agents at Alexandria:
Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld
